column10: Drought impacts households, e.g., through water shortages, restrictions in water use or dependence on alternative water sources (e.g. the number of days per year with water use regulation on certain areas, number of households there). It can affect food security or cause economic strain increased costs (water, electricity). Indicator can also just describe the number of households in a high risk area.

column8: Change in occurrence of vector-borne diseases
column9:
https://atlas.ecdc.europa.eu/public/index.aspx 

https://climate-adapt.eea.europa.eu/en/observatory/evidence/health-effects/vector-borne-diseases 

Paz, S., 2021, Climate change impacts on vector-borne diseases in Europe: risks, predictions and actions, The Lancet Regional Health - Europe 1, 100017. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.lanepe.2020.100017

Semenza, J.C., 2015, Prototype early warning systems for vector-borne diseases in Europe, International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health 12(6): 6333–6351. https://doi.org/10.3390/ijerph120606333 

Semenza, J.C. & Suk, J.E., 2018, Vector-borne diseases and climate change: a European perspective, FEMS Microbiology Letters 365(2), fnx244. https://doi.org/10.1093/femsle/fnx244
column10: Climate change can have an influence on vector-borne disease (VBD) transmission as climatic conditions affect the life cycle of disease vectors (e.g., mosquitos, ticks,...) and the replication rates of viruses and parasites inside the vectors. Increased temperatures may shorten vector reproduction cycles and incubation periods for vector-borne pathogens, leading to larger vector populations and increased transmission risks. Changes in temperatures, precipitations and humidity could affect both the geographic distribution and seasonal activity of vectors and host animals, as well as human behaviours and land use patterns, and as such the overall prevalence of VBDs (source: https://climate-adapt.eea.europa.eu/en/metadata/adaptation-options/early-warning-systems-for-vector-borne-diseases).
column12: Location and number of disease occurrences in target area
column14: Mean winter low temperatures (or other e.g. tick spead precondition)
column16: Location and number of disease occurrences in target area

column8: Drought-related disturbances to agricultural livelihoods
column9:
Annual Crop Yield Reduction: Measures the decrease in crop yields (tons/hectare or % change) during drought years compared to average or baseline years. 
Source: Indicator-to-impact links to help improve agricultural drought preparedness in Thailand, Nat. Hazards Earth Syst. Sci., 23, 2419–2441, https://doi.org/10.5194/nhess-23-2419-2023, 2023.

Farm Business Profit/Loss: Assesses changes in farm income or profit margins attributable to drought events, often using outcome-based modeling systems
Source: Monitoring agricultural and economic drought: the Australian Agricultural Drought Indicators (AADI). https://doi.org/10.5194/egusphere-2024-3731
column10: Refers to the disruptions and challenges to agricultural sector due to prolonged periods of low rainfall or water shortages. These disturbances can be, e.g., crop failure (especially "cash crops" that farmers rely on for livelihood), reduced yield, loss of seedlings, rising costs. Could also be measured in loss of income, increase in debt or unemployment.

Percentage of Population Affected by Water Scarcity: Measures the share of the population living in areas experiencing water scarcity for at least one quarter of the year.
Example: In 2022, 34% of the EU population was affected by water scarcity conditions during at least one quarter of the year

Tracks the number of residents subject to water use restrictions, rationing, or supply interruptions during drought or scarcity events.

column8: Areas vulnerable to wildfires
column9:
Wildfire Risk Index: Integrates fire danger (likelihood of fire due to weather and fuel conditions) with vulnerability (exposure of people, ecosystems, and assets).
Used at the pan-European scale to rank and map areas by wildfire risk
Source: 
EFFIS - European Forest Fire Information System. https://forest-fire.emergency.copernicus.eu/

Pan-European wildfire risk assessment: https://data.effis.emergency.copernicus.eu/effis/reports-and-publications/effis-related-publications/The+Pan-European+wildfire+risk+assessment+report+2022.pdf

Global data-driven prediction of fire activity
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58097-6

Fire Weather Index (FWI): A meteorological index (e.g., the Canadian FWI) that assesses daily fire danger based on temperature, humidity, wind, and precipitation. Used to monitor current and projected fire danger across Europe
Sources:
https://www.eea.europa.eu/en/analysis/indicators/forest-fires-in-europe?activeAccordion=ecdb3bcf-bbe9-4978-b5cf-0b136399d9f8 

Venäläinen, A., Korhonen, N., Hyvärinen, O., Koutsias, N., Xystrakis, F., Urbieta, I. R. and Moreno, J. M., 2014, 'Temporal variations and change in forest fire danger in Europe for 1960–2012', Natural Hazards and Earth System Sciences 14(6), pp. 1477–1490 ( https://www.nat-hazards-earth-syst-sci.net/14/1477/2014/ ) accessed September 26, 2019

column10: Describes the amount, percentage or areal distribution of weather-related damages and assesses the extent of harm inflicted on forest ecosystems resulting from extreme weather phenomena, such as storms, droughts, floods, and wildfires. This indicator is essential for understanding the vulnerability of forested areas to climate change. Certain forest types and species are more susceptible to weather-related damage, e.g., young or aging forests may lack the structural integrity to withstand severe storms, while invasive species can exacerbate the impact of climate stressors.

column8: Share of permeable surfaces in urban environments
column9:
Soil sealing is a comprehensive indicator that characterises aspects of a large number of measures, such as the proportion of green space, structural development and land use (Murata and Kawai2018).Reduced sealing therefore indicates reduced heating of surfaces and increased water permeability, which is important for reducing both heat- and water-related risks (Fokaides et al. 2016) (Source: Patel et al 2025 https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).

Additional sources:

https://doi.org/10.1080/00380768.2018.1439342 

https://doi.org/10.1177/1420326x16644495 

Luti, T., S. Segoni, F. Catani, M. Munafò, and N. Casagli. 2020. “Integration of Remotely Sensed Soil Sealing Data in Landslide Susceptibility Mapping.”Remote Sensing 12, no.9:1486

https://doi.org/10.1127/metz/2021/1074

García,P., M.E.Pérez, and A.Guerra. 2014. “Using TM Images to Detect Soil Sealing Change in Madrid (Spain).” Geoderma 214–215:135–140
column10: Describes the share of permeable surfaces in urban environment, related to risk of pluvial flooding. Can also be related to human comfort during heat.

column8: Share of forested area
column9:
Tree cover describes the proportion of the area that is covered by trees or a considerable amount of vegetation. Trees, on the other hand, have more than just positive effects for urban residents. For instance, densely planted trees cool less at night than open meadow areas (Spronken-SmithandOke1999). In addition, tree avenues with canopy closures on busy streets can increase the concentration of air pollutants due to reduced mixing (Venter et al. 2024) (source: Patel et al 2025, https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).

Additional sources:

Spronken-Smith, R.A., and T.R.Oke. 1999. “Scale Modelling of Nocturnal Cooling in Urban Parks.” Boundary-Layer Meteorology 93:287–312.

Venter, Z. S., A. Hassani, E. Stange, P. Schneider, and N. Castell. 2024. “Reassessing the Role of Urban Green Space in Air Pollution Control.” Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 121, no. 6: e2306200121. https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2306200121. 

Meier,F., and D.Scherer. 2012. “Spatial and Temporal Variability of Urban Tree Canopy Temperature During Summer 2010 in Berlin, Germany.” Theoretical and Applied Climatology 110, no. 3: 373–384. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00704-012-0631-0.

column10: Assesses the water balance of a field by comparing water inputs with plant water use through evapotranspiration.
column35: Area, geometry and culture type in a shp file

column8: Vulnerability of crops to climatic hazards
column10: This indicator takes the form of a toolbox. It can be used to select a crop and highlight the risks associated with the climate at certain key moments in the vegetative development process.
column33: Historical and projected daily wind speed

column8: Impact of climate change on annual crops yield
column10: This indicator is based on the AquaCrop crop growth model developed by the Land and Water Division of FAO to address food security and to assess the effect of environment and management on crop production. AquaCrop simulates yield response to water of herbaceous crops, and is particularly suited to address conditions where water is a key limiting factor in crop production.
column30: Historical and projected Daily values of Reference evapotranspiration
column33: Historical and projected Mean annual CO2 concentrations
column37: Local expertise (soils physical parameters, field management practices, ...)

column8: Population vulnerability to heat waves
column9:
Indicators such as heat-related mortality rates and the heat vul nerability index (HVI) are examples of population vulnerability index. These indexes consider various factors, such as age, health status and mortality due to other diseases, in addition to heat stress for calculation.
However,it is challenging to gather all the data required for the calculation at the city at national level. See Wolf and McGregor (2013, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.wace.2013.07.004) for methodological approach to calculating HVI in their work. https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2212094713000054?via%3Dihub
column10: Level of vulnerability of populations to a heat wave aggravated by the potential UHI (urban heat island) effect. Use I1021 and I1003
column12: Income level or poverty level of households

column8: LCZ vulnerability level
column9:
Local climate zones (LCZs) are a classification of a city’s block geometry and land cover in view of the effects on the local urban climate(Jiaetal.2024).The concept of LCZs has contributed to a better understanding and comparability of the intensity of UHI (Stewart and Oke2012),as this concept can be useful for various urban climate or microclimate variables (source: Patel et al 2025 https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).
See:
https://doi.org/10.1007/s11783-017-0984-9 
https://doi.org/10.3390/ijgi10080539 
https://doi.org/10.3390/su12198083 
https://doi.org/10.1109/JSTARS.2012.2189873
column10: Vulnerability class of the unit of analysis to urban heat islands in relation to the local climate zone class to which it belongs

column8: Quality and structure of the green network
column10: This index is a weighted sum of most relevant biodiversity indicators such as share of green, canopy and herbaceous area as well as connectivity and distance between canopy areas

column8: Share of green area
column9:
The indicator green cover indicates the proportion of public green spaces covering the entire city or a district (with a recommended target of 30%–40%). This 30%–40% of green coverin the form of public and private green spaces would contribute to a significant air temperature reduction in cities. This indicator is calculated using the total area of all green spaces available under the atmospheric canopy in proportion to the total area of land (Patel et al 2025, https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).

Additional sources:
Zhao, C., G. Fu, X. Liu, and F. Fu. 2011. “Urban Planning Indicators,
Morphology and Climate Indicators: A Case Study for a North-South
TransectofBeijing,China.”BuildingandEnvironment46,no.5:1174–1183.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.buildenv.2010.12.009
column10: Percentage of the surface area of the unit of analysis occupied by vegetation (private and public spaces combined)
column28: Research to be done - the data should be available

column8: Share of canopy area
column9:
The urban canopy layer height has a significant effect on UHI. The study done by Zauli Sajani et al. (2008) mentioned that the canopy layer height temperature measurements generally underestimate the values of UHI compared to the 10- and 2- m temperature measurement stations. However, canopy layer height measurements fo rurban climate studies are not common, though they provide significant information for understanding the UHI effects (MaShaoXiuetal.2017) (Patel et al 2025, https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009).
Sources:
https://doi.org/10.1007/s00484-008-0171-6 
https://www.cabidigitallibrary.org/doi/full/10.5555/20183020539

column8: Land Surface temperature
column9:
High-resolution land surface temperature (LST) data are often freely available online, and it is valuable for understanding the temperature vulnerability on a smaller scale. To derive LST, remote sensing data are predominantly used. However, using LST as an indicator has some limitations, in particular that it cannot directly contribute to calculating human thermal comfort levels. Moreover,LST requires land surface emissivity (LSE) in the calculation methodologies (Patel et al 2025; https://doi.org/10.1002/cli2.70009). 
Related sources: 
https://doi.org/10.1029/2022RG000777 
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scs.2017.03.013 
https://doi.org/10.1007/s40808-023-01822-2
column10: Mean Land surface temperature  in the unit of analysis under consideration
